Research Notes • Brandon McKinzie • Fall 2016


DL Research Notes

Brandon McKinzie


  1. Black Hat Talk

    • Title: “Deep Learning on Disassembly” [link]

    • Disassembly appears to refer to the process of converting machine language → assembly language (the inverse opera- tion of an assembler). Relevance to talk:

      Starting with a brief explanation of deep learning, we then work through the different pieces of the pipeline to go from a collection of raw binaries, to extraction and transformation of disassembly data, and training of a deep learning model.

    • Overview:

      • Want to find automated way to detect malware.

      • Example input data: executa- bles/documents/scripts/etc.

      • Labels could be binary (malware/not malware) or clas- sify different types of malware.

      • For an executable, features could be filesize, strings,

        n-grams, entropy of sections, etc.


    • Some ML/DL review:

      • Reviews concept of 2D Convolution, wherein each pixel in a 2D grid has a convolution kernel applied that computes a weighted sum of the surrounding pixels. The convolution kernel is designed to pick out some desired characteristic(s) from the original input.

      • Convolutional Neural Networks consist of repeating layer groups, e.g. convolution layer → RELU → POOL

        → CONV → RELU · · · and so on.

    • Applying to malware detection:

      • Disassemble assembly to hex encoding1. Store binary as grid of instructions as pixels.

      • Clear patterns are seen in the image of pixelized in- structions.

      • Note: PE = Windows Portable Executable. Typical format of malicious binaries.


    1Appears to define disassemble in opposite way to most definitions online. His way makes more sense.

  2. Initial Meeting Notes

  • Fuzzing: generation of inputs to break a progeram. Inter- ested in making unusable .


  • Goal:

    • pick up where other ppl left off on security. Take care of fuzzing itself.

    • Take care of the instrumentation. Modeling the way the program works. Give inputs to receive stats on what function calls were made.


  • Three sources of info:

    • instrumentation info, structure

    • inputs modeling

    • The way the inputs affect the program.


  • Problem is input is fluid. Need to generalize inputs.

  • Example: one program received 2 arrays of char. ret true if match in the two.


    • feed to program with linear regression.


  • The network will be able to learn what inputs render the program unusable.


  • Long run: create something that is generic, can learn from .

    • Start with singular programs. get binary inputs, have program.

    • with basic architecture. 4 convulations. few fully convulioted. Represent as bytes and feed to network. Have network infer what’s best.


  • identify problems we will have later

  • benchmark

  • Want to come up with list of features.

    • number of functions

    • function sequence

    • memory usage


  • automatic generation: grow it in scala.

  • Action Items:

    • Read papers.

    • Black hat talk.

  • TF with goal of 3 separate inputs concat to single input. Connect it to a network. No RNN, just feedforward. Transform malware to input as images. Create a few separate networks and connect them later.

  • DPPN genetic algorithm and gradient descent
